MATHEMATICS

You will need: List of formulae (MF19)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|>
- Answer all questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 761, 467]]<|/det|>
- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 565, 497]]<|/det|>
- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|>
- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 528]]<|/det|>
- Do not write on any bar codes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 867, 545]]<|/det|>
- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 482, 575]]<|/det|>
- You should use a calculator where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 881, 591]]<|/det|>
- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 854, 620]]<|/det|>
- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 669, 214, 680]]<|/det|>
# INFORMATION

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 683, 388, 698]]<|/det|>
- The total mark for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 715]]<|/det|>
- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 918, 96]]<|/det|>
1 A curve has equation \(y=5+3 x-2 x^{2}\) and a straight line has equation \(y=k x+13\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 109, 675, 126]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which the curve and the line do not meet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
2

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[350, 87, 648, 339]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 349, 918, 378]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y=2 x^{2}-\frac{5}{x}+3\). The curve crosses the \(x\)-axis at the point \(P(1,0)\) and \(M\) is a minimum point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 410, 432, 426]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the gradient of the curve at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 620, 777, 638]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the coordinates of \(M\). Give each coordinate correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 487, 109]]<|/det|>
3 (a) Find the complete expansion of \(\left(2 x-\frac{3}{x}\right)^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 540, 747, 573]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence determine the coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \(\left(x^{2}+5\right)\left(2 x-\frac{3}{x}\right)^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
4

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[372, 87, 625, 264]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 285, 827, 301]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a triangle \(O A B\) where \(O A=O B=10 \mathrm{~cm}\) and angle \(A O B=0.8\) radians. Points \(C\) and \(D\) on \(O A\) and \(O B\) respectively are such that the \(\operatorname{arc} C D\) is part of a circle with centre \(O\) and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 316, 869, 333]]<|/det|>
radius 6 cm . The shaded region is bounded by the \(\operatorname{arc} C D\) and the line segments \(C A, A B\) and \(B D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 346, 471, 364]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 652, 430, 671]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 653, 91]]<|/det|>
5 An arithmetic progression has first term 5 and common difference 6 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 736, 122]]<|/det|>
For this progression, find the sum of all the terms that lie between 150 and 400.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
6

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 91, 611, 263]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 281, 918, 300]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle \(C\) of radius \(r\), where \(x>0\) and \(y>0\) for all points on \(C\). The least distance between any point on \(C\) and the \(x\)-axis is 8 units, and the least distance between any point on \(C\) and the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 314, 247, 330]]<|/det|>
\(y\)-axis is 5 units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 343, 625, 362]]<|/det|>
(a) State the coordinates of the centre of the circle in terms of \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 404, 918, 423]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that the distance between the origin and the centre of the circle is 15 units, find the value of \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 695, 653, 715]]<|/det|>
(c) The point on the circle furthest from the origin is denoted by \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 727, 540, 746]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the tangent to the circle at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 825, 91]]<|/det|>
8 A geometric progression is such that its second term is - 120 and its sum to infinity is 160 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 341, 122]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the common ratio.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 476, 601, 493]]<|/det|>
(b) The first nine terms of the progression are now removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 508, 672, 524]]<|/det|>
Find the sum to infinity of the remaining terms of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 834, 113]]<|/det|>
9 A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}}=\frac{6}{x^{4}}-\frac{5}{x^{3}}\). It is given that the curve has a stationary point at \(\left(\frac{1}{2}, 9\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 119, 921, 159]]<|/det|>
(a) Use the expression for \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}}\) to determine whether the stationary point is a maximum or a minimum point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 310, 399, 327]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 105, 90]]<|/det|>
10

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[315, 91, 659, 292]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 310, 461, 327]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 336, 594, 360]]<|/det|>
\[
y=4(3 x+4)^{\frac{1}{2}}-2 x-6
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 372, 918, 389]]<|/det|>
for values of \(x\) such that \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 7\). The tangent to the curve at the point \(P(7,0)\) meets the \(y\)-axis at the point \(Q\). Region \(A\) is bounded by the curve and the two axes. Region \(B\) is bounded by the curve, the line

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 404, 335, 421]]<|/det|>
segment \(P Q\) and the \(y\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 433, 358, 452]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the area of region \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 548, 91]]<|/det|>
11 Functions \(f\) and \(g\) are defined for all real values of \(x\) by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[357, 101, 642, 122]]<|/det|>
\[
f(x)=4 x^{2}-c \text { and } g(x)=2 x+k
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 653, 153]]<|/det|>
where \(c\) and \(k\) are positive constants. It is given that \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(3 k+1)=c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 395, 184]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(\mathrm{gf}(x)=8 x^{2}-k-1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 918, 96]]<|/det|>
(b) The curve with equation \(y=8 x^{2}-k-1\) is transformed to the curve with equation \(y=\mathrm{h}(x)\) by the following sequence of transformations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 117, 338, 151]]<|/det|>
Translation of \(\binom{2}{3}\) Stretch in the \(y\)-direction by scale factor \(k\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 168, 380, 184]]<|/det|>
Reflection in the \(x\)-axis

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 197, 529, 216]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{h}(x)\) in terms of \(x\) and \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 454, 525]]<|/det|>
(c) The range of h is given by \(\mathrm{h}(x) \leqslant 15\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 536, 366, 555]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(c\) and \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
